title.narrative: Drought Mitigation in the Republic of the Marshall Islands

description.narrative: Remote islands in the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) largely depend on rainwater as their primary source of drinking water, and the majority of accessible shallow wells are brackish and not utilized for drinking purposes. To support RMI Government’s drought mitigation work and current reverse osmosis (RO) units and supplies, IOM is providing water, sanitation and hygiene focused interventions to meet priorities expressed through the RMI Immediate Drought Response Plan 2022. Mitigation-focused interventions include the provision of RO spare and replacement parts for existing RO units and training of technicians to ensure maintenance and sustained operation. IOM is also supporting the National Disaster Management Office in technical logistics during deployment and community focused drought mitigation training. Acting at an early stage and before water resources dwindle to a crisis level will foremost prevent loss of life and minimize suffering, but also reduce expenditure. Were the situation to reach a crisis level, it would necessitate rapid (and costly) deployment of lifesaving assets via air and sea to these remote locations.
